instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS: What is PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS? PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS is 20v in from the USB-C charger on USB-C powered Macbook Pros..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v only
threads.message:
Hello. I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that was liquid damaged but it has been previously worked on and cleaned so I don't know where exactly the liquid damage was. Amp meter shows 5v 0.03a on all 4 ports, but 2 of the ports power cycle every couple seconds and then other 2 do not. I know if the port shows steady 5v instead of cycling, that there is an issue on the corresponding <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip, but I have replaced both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips for the ports that are steady 5v and have gotten no change. I replaced each one twice just to be safe but they still show steady 5v 0.03a. Diode mode values on each of the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips seem similar so not sure where to check next. Here are some voltage and diode mode measurements.

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP> (Steady 5v):
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.32v - 0.337
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XA_VBUS</SIGNAL> - 5.17v - 0.16
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.29v - 0.476   
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 1.78v - 0.484
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 1.8v - 0.449
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 0v - 0.464

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> (5v loop):
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.34v - 0.337
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS</SIGNAL> - 5.17v - 0.16
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.29v - 0.476
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 1.8v - 0.491
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 1.8v - 0.457
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 1.1v - 0.47

UB300 (5v loop):
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.34v - 0.337
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_TA_VBUS</SIGNAL> - 5.17v - 0.159
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.3v - 0.476
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 1.8v - 0.492
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 1.8v - 0.459
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 1.1v - 0.476

UB400 (Steady 5v):
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.34v - 0.337
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_TB_VBUS</SIGNAL> - 5.1v - 0.159
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TB_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.28v - 0.475
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 1.8v - 0.511
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 1.8v - 0.472
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 1.1v - 0.496

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v only
threads.message:
Seems to have a problem on <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> area; doesn't have 1V1 LDO.
Be aware of new chips from China, many fake...

Do you get <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v only
threads.message: Yea <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 3.3v. I will check <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> again and see if I can find any issues.
